title: Boy diagnosed with dementia at 5 can only remember how to say ‘mummy’
text:
Reece Mitchell and his mum Donna Mitchell (Picture: SWNS)

A boy has forgotten almost everything he has learned in his short life after being diagnosed with childhood dementia.

Reece Mitchell, now six, only remembers how to say mummy, with doctors saying he can expect to live another six years at most.

He has Batten’s disease – a rare form of childhood dementia which has no cure.

It has also left him completely blind, unable to drink and eat properly and needing a wheelchair.

Single-mum Donna Mitchell, 46, from North Kessock, Scotland, is devastated but has vowed to remain positive and make the most of what little time Reece has left.

She said: ‘Despite being just six, Reece has taught us more about life and love than anyone.

‘Unfortunately, you only properly appreciate life when it’s threatened, and Reece is losing a little more of his life with every day.

‘I occasionally see a glimmer of the old Reece, when he lets out a cheeky smile or reaches for my hand, but this disease has stolen his character and his spark – I wouldn’t wish it on my worst enemy.’

Reece was diagnosed with Batten’s disease – a rare form of childhood dementia (Picture: SWNS)

Reece is still trying to enjoy life (Picture: SWNS)

Reece started having seizures when he was a toddler, and while doctors initially linked it to his autism, tests revealed it was much more serious.

The toddler initially flourished at main-stream nursery with the help of learning support assistants, hitting his milestones like any other child his age.

In January 2017 however, he started to suffer from worrying seizures, which got increasingly worse and more frequent as time went on.

He was eventually diagnosed with Batten’s disease in September 2018.

Mum-of-three Ms Mitchell, who worked with adults with special needs, had to give up work to take care of Reece full-time.

Ms Mitchell added: ‘We weren’t going to wallow in self-pity and I refuse to be sad while he’s still here,” Donna said.

‘The girls and I will enjoy the time we have left with him, and have already been lucky enough to go on some amazing trips.’

What is Batten’s disease? Batten’s disease is a rare form of childhood dementia which has no cure.

The condition has a life expectancy of just 12-years-old.

It affects an estimated 100 – 150 children in the UK.

Only 50 children have the same strain of the disease as Reece, known as CLN2.

The terminal illness leaves children suffering from cognitive impairment, seizures, and progressive loss of sight and motor skills.

Early symptoms of the condition appear between the ages of five and ten years.

The disease is inherited, with both parents having to be carriers of the faulty gene.

Reece can now only say ‘mummy’ (Picture: SWNS)

Reece’s condition causes frequent seizures (Picture: SWNS)

Last December, the family visited Lapland thanks to a local charity called Mikeysline, and Make a Wish have also gifted them a visit to Knockhill Race Track so Reece could enjoy his love of cars.

They have also been invited to the fire station and police station, where Reece has met his ‘heroes’ and pretended to drive in the engines.

Ms Mitchell said: ‘It’s amazing to see his eyes light up when we go to these events.

‘It doesn’t happen very often but I know my little boy is still in there, even if it’s deep down.’

Ms Mitchell with Reece when a few days old (Picture: SWNS)

Reece in March 2018 aged 5 (Picture: SWNS)

The Batten Disease Family Association has provided the family with information to help them cope with his condition.

Batten’s disease, which has no cure, affects an estimated 100 – 150 children in the UK, with only 50 having the same strain as Reece, known as CLN2.

It leaves children suffering from cognitive impairment, seizures, and progressive loss of sight and motor skills.

Early symptoms of the terminal illness appear between the ages of five and ten years.

The condition is inherited, with both parents having to be carriers of the faulty gene.

Both Ms Mitchell’s other children Courtney, 26, and Alexandra, 16, decided to be tested, but won’t have the results back for a while.
